text.p: These are the leading stories in the Malawi press on Wednesday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Two people were injured when the ruling United Democratic Front (UDF) party supporters on Tuesday afternoon clashed with the opposition Alliance for Democracy (AFORD) at a by-election campaign rally in a Blantyre township.

- John Carter, group chief executive for Press Corporation, the country's biggest conglomerate, has been dismissed with immediate effect. Carter said, however, that he had resigned on his own and was intending to leave the country anytime.

The government is involved in a Supreme Court action against the main opposition Malawi Congress Party (MCP) in a bid to take over the corporation's trust from former president Kamuzu Banda who claims its ownership.

- The newly formed United Council for Dialogue (UCD) comprising nine opposition parties not represented in parliament condemned the ruling UDF for hiring expensive foreign lawyers to help government in its court action over the Press Trust.
- Police headquarters on Tuesday confirmed there were salary and allowance grievances among junior police officers.
